headline.main: BROOKLYN CITY.; JUSTICES. MORE LIGHT. CHILD MISSING. CITY HALL. MORTALITY. ACCIDENT. ROWDIES HELD TO BAIL. FOUND DROWNED. FOUND DEAD. POLICE COURT CITY COURT. CIRCUIT COURT, AND COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER. CITY COURT CALENDAR.

docs.lead_paragraph: MORE ROWDYISM-ASSAULT WITH ATTEMPT TO KILL.--Late on Sunday night, a gang of six rowdies entered the Union Hotel, No. 1 Atlantic street, kept by TIhOMAS COSTIGAN, and made an attack upon the proprietor, without any provocation whatever. Decanters and tumblers were thrown at his head, and finally one of the party seized an oyster-knife aid attempted to stab him.

headline.main: FRANCE.; The Press in Paris--Napoleon mortal and subject to Boils--Pathology of Sea-sickness --The Bourae Sensitive--House Cleaning Theatrical--Miscellaneous.

docs.lead_paragraph: As if the law-suit just brought against Dr. VERON for the sale of the Constitutionnel had not sunk both the editor and the paper into sufficient disgrace-for the revelations are such as will compromise them both beyond recovery-the chaste and pi ous organ of family and religion makes an announcement this week which opens the eyes of the Parisians to a width beyond their usual stretch.

docs.lead_paragraph: The famous Dr. WILLIAM BEAUMONT, whose " Physiology of Digestion and Experiments on the Gastric Juice," based on the experiments he conducted upon the Canadian ALEXIS ST. MARTIN, have made him so widely and favorably known, died on the 25th ult., at St. Louis. Dr. BEAUMONT was a native of Lebanon, Connecticut, where he was born 1785. In 1812,

docs.lead_paragraph: Rev. DAVID P. BAILEY died at Aurora, Ill., on the 15th ult. He had been the pastor of the Universalist Church in Aurora but a few months. Rev. Father DE HANN, formerly of St. Joseph's Church, New-Orleans, died a few days since. Dr. IRA CORWIN of Southold, Suffolk Co., died, 'aged about 70 years, at his home after a very brief illness on the 6th of April. He had practiced

docs.lead_paragraph: On the evening of the 15th, the great source was given at Glasgow, in honor of Mrs. H. BEECHER STOWE. Two thousand persons were present, hundreds of whom had taken their place an hour, at least, before the proceedings commenced. Mr. McDOWALL, of Glasgow, presided. After tea, Rev. Dr. WARDLAW moved the first resolution, welcoming to Glasgow Mrs. STOWE, and including in the welcome Rev. C. E. STOWE.

docs.lead_paragraph: Why the corners of our streets should have the privilege--guaranteed by the common seal of the City--of destroying health, property, education and life, it is difficult to conjecture. Nevertheless it is true that such high prerogatives are vested, by corporate authority, in these particular localities.
